awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Inference by Social Sampling
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning and inference in distributed settings is an important from both a scientific and engineering perspective.  A typical instance of the problem is a network of individual sensors or agents attempting to infer a global distribution that governs their local observations.  By passing messages the agents can individually make inference about a global phenomenon.  This research investigates communication and networking paradigms that can enable a network of individual agents to collaboratively estimate distributions over high dimensional spaces, even when individual observations are severely limited in accuracy, space, or time. 

In particular, the investigators study how individual decision makers can integrate two kinds of information: local observations and messages from their neighbors in the network.  Both observation and messaging can be thought of as sampling : individuals sample their own environment and sample the opinions of their neighbors.  Central to the approach is that the agents generate simple messages at random from an internal estimate of the global distribution of interest.  The first major goal of this project is to develop a mathematical framework and analysis techniques to understand if and when this limited form of learning and communication is sufficient for an individual to estimate and learn distributions and/or global parameters governing the observations of all nodes.   The technical approach is a blend of analysis techniques ranging from stochastic approximation, randomized algorithms, and statistical physics.  

Applications for this work range from mathematical modeling of messages and opinion formation in social networks, communication protocols for distributed optimization, and estimation of parameters in data networks.  The work will cover several related problems : estimating high-dimensional histograms of data held in the network, parametric estimation using a mix of Bayesian and non-Bayesian techniques, and estimation of more complex generative models.  The final part of the work is to apply these methods to peer-peer networks and social network modeling.  The broader impact of this work is to further develop the interdisciplinary field of network science, which impacts both quantitative social sciences and engineering.  The PIs will develop educational materials and organize research activities to help bring together different research communities interested in networks and social learning.

por.por_cntn:
This project was about distributed learning in networks. Agents/nodes in the network collect information locally from, e.g. sensor observations, and socially, from neighbors in the network.  The goal is to estimate some global parameter governing the data.  The proposal is focused on the case where both kinds of data come from sampling – nodes (randomly) sample from a local probability distribution and receive samples (randomly) drawn from the beliefs of their neighbors.

From the proposal, we had 3 specific research outcomes, as summarized below:

Specific Aim 1. Suppose the agents are severely limited in the number of local samples collected; in an extreme case each agent begins with a private sample. In this setting, network wide empirical density of privately collected samples is a natural statistic useful for inference. We studied the close connection between distributed learning of distributions and stochastic approximation. The result of our finding was published in a journal article which appeared in IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control. 

Specific Aim 2. Suppose there is a global parameter that governs agents' local sampling process through conditional distributions (or local observation channels, from a communication perspective). When these local channels are not sufficient to recover the underlying parameter in a local fashion, individuals must share and learn from each other in order to accurately estimate the parameter. We have shown that a combination of local Bayesian updating and sharing samples from the posterior beliefs is sufficient for estimation. These findings have appeared in the proceedings of two peer-reviewed IEEE conferences and have been submitted to IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. 

Specific Aim 3.  We have investigated the applicability of the proposed ideas in context of distributed spectrum sensing and enhanced spectrum access. The findings will appear in a conference paper. The evaluations against real data is an important aspect of this study. 

The broader impact of this award included organizing three annual invited sessions on the topic of distributed learning at the Information Theory and Applications Workshop (2014-2016). The sessions brought researchers across the country and the world to discuss the problem of networked and distributed learning from an analytical and engineering point of view. Furthermore, the award supported and trained a female electical and computer engineering PhD student at UCSD as well as providing research experience opportunity for three undergraduate students, two of which were recruited from under-represented minority student organizations on campus. The award directly impacted and broadened the participation in research by member of underserved and under represented communities.
